questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery

 

Cornual block, also known as proximal tubal obstruction, can be effectively managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation, typically guided by hysteroscopy and laparoscopy. This method has about an 85% success rate in restoring tubal patency, making it the next logical step in management for a woman with a bilateral cornual block.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Cornual Block: Proximal tubal obstructions often require intervention to restore patency.
  • Hysteroscopy and Laparoscopy: These procedures allow for precise catheterization and cannulation to open the blocked tubes, leading to a high success rate.
  • Success Rate: Approximately 85% success in restoring tubal patency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuboplasty: While tuboplasty is an option for distal tubal occlusion, it is not the first-line treatment for cornual block.

 

Option C. Hydrotubation: This procedure involves flushing the tubes with fluid but is less effective for treating cornual block compared to hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery. Success rates are poor (15-30 %)

 

Option D. In-vitro fertilization: IVF is typically considered when surgical interventions fail or are not suitable, particularly in women over 35 or those with severe tubal damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cornual block in a young woman with primary infertility should be managed with hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation to restore tubal patency before considering more invasive options like IVF.

 

Ref: Page 1158, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

choices.text: HRT to induce puberty

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, no breast development and Prader 3 genitalia was found to have raised FSH. Her karyotype revealed 45 X0/46 XY and an ultrasound revealed Mullerian structures with poorly visualized gonads. What would be the next line of management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral gonadectomy

 

  • This patient has gonadal dysgenesis with virilization (Prader 3 classification is used to describe the degree of virilization of external genitalia)

 

 

  • If a Y-chromosome is identified during evaluation of primary amenorrhoea, laparoscopic prophylactic gonadectomy is recommended at the time of diagnosis to eliminate the risk of malignancy as dysgenetic gonads have a very high risk of malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. HRT to induce puberty: After gonadectomy, then HRT can be given for secondary sexual development

 

Option D. Clitoroplasty and Option A. vaginoplasty and other surgeries to correct the virilization may be required but the immediate next step would be to do gonadectomy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whenever there is 46XY with primary amenorrhoea, always gonadectomy needs to be done in view of high risk of malignancy in dysgenetic gonads

 

Ref: Speroff’s Textbook of Reproductive Medicine

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of amenorrhea has the following findings: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HELLP syndrome

 

HELLP Syndrome:

 

  • The given clinical scenario with elevated liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT), elevated bilirubin, low platelet count, and hypertension is indicative of HELLP syndrome.
  • HELLP is an acronym for:
    • Hemolysis (H): Evidence of hemolysis can include elevated LDH.
    • Elevated Liver enzymes (EL): Both SGOT and SGPT are elevated.
    • Low Platelet count (LP): Platelet count is significantly reduced (below 100,000/mm³).
  • This syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management often involves the termination of pregnancy, with steroid cover for fetal lung maturity and magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis and neuroprotection of the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy:

 

  • This condition typically occurs during the late second and third trimesters.
  • Diagnosis is based on the Swansea Criteria, requiring 6 or more specific findings, which often include renal impairment, liver impairment, hypoglycemia, and coagulation defects.
  • Liver biopsy would show microvascular steatosis.

 

 

Option C. Viral Hepatitis:

 

  • Viral hepatitis can occur at any gestational age and presents with jaundice.
  • It typically involves markedly elevated bilirubin and significantly raised SGOT and SGPT levels.
  • This scenario lacks the characteristic very high bilirubin levels seen in viral hepatitis.

 

Option D. Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy:

 

  • Usually occurs in the third trimester and presents with pruritus.
  • Lab findings typically show mildly elevated bilirubin, elevated SGOT and SGPT, and characteristically raised serum bile acids.
  • Renal impairment, high BP, and coagulation abnormalities are not seen in intrahepatic cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. It is a severe form of preeclampsia and necessitates urgent medical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 1809, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has an adnexal mass with slightly elevated CA 125, normal CA 19-9, and elevated LDH. Post-surgery, the tumor is soft, fleshy, and solid with a yellow-white to gray-pink appearance. Microscopic examination reveals large vesicular cells with clear cytoplasm, well-defined cell boundaries, and centrally placed regular nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dysgerminoma

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings are consistent with a dysgerminoma. This tumor typically appears as a soft, fleshy mass with a solid yellow-white to gray-pink cut surface. Microscopically, it is identified by large vesicular cells with clear cytoplasm, well-defined cell boundaries, and centrally placed nuclei. These cells are arranged in sheets or cords separated by scant fibrous stroma infiltrated by lymphocytes. Elevated LDH is also commonly associated with dysgerminomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma - This type of tumor typically shows papillary structures and may have psammoma bodies, which is not consistent with the features described.

 

Option C. Teratoma - Teratomas usually contain a mix of tissues from different germ layers, including elements like hair or teeth, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma - Choriocarcinomas are characterized by trophoblastic cells and typically present with significantly elevated hCG levels, not elevated LDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysgerminomas present with large vesicular cells, clear cytoplasm, well-defined boundaries, and centrally placed nuclei, appearing as a soft, fleshy, yellow-white to gray-pink mass, often with elevated LDH levels.

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period
Beta HCG estimation
Serum FSH and LH

questions.text: A patient has been on MALA-N for 6 months. She is compliant, but she complained of missed periods. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta HCG estimation

 

MALA-N is a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). Despite high compliance, all contraceptive methods have a failure rate. The first consideration for a missed period in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy. Therefore, the next step is to estimate beta HCG levels to rule out pregnancy.

 

  • Beta HCG Estimation: This is essential to confirm or rule out pregnancy. Serum beta HCG can detect pregnancy as early as five days before the first missed period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This is not the initial step. It is more appropriate once pregnancy is confirmed or other issues are suspected.

 

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While some irregularity can occur with OCPs, pregnancy must be ruled out first.

 

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: These tests are used to evaluate ovarian function but are not appropriate for initial evaluation of a missed period in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills presents with a missed period, the first step is to rule out pregnancy by estimating beta HCG levels.

 

Ref: Page no 622, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Do UPT and then give DMPA

questions.text: A female patient taking DMPA came 14 days late. What should be advised to her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give DMPA, no backup required

 

When a patient is up to 15 days late for a Depo-Provera (DMPA) injection, it is generally safe to administer the injection without additional contraceptive backup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do UPT and then give DMPA: Pregnancy testing is typically not required unless the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option B. DMPA + 7 days backup: Backup contraception is recommended if the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option C. DMPA from next cycle: There is no need to wait until the next cycle if the delay is within 15 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients receiving DMPA who are less than 15 days late for their injection, it can be administered without the need for additional contraceptive measures or delay.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Studdiford criteria

 

  • Studdiford Criteria is for diagnosis of Primary abdominal pregnancy
    • Both tubes and ovaries normal with no marks of injury
    • Utero-peritoneal fistula should not be seen
    • The placenta should be attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiegelberg Criteria: Spiegelberg Criteria is for Ovarian ectopic

 

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestation sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • The gestation sac in the ovary must be connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall on histopathology

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Rubin criteria is for Cervical pregnancy

 

Option D. Ring of fire: Ring of fire is a sign seen on USG-Color doppler in an unruptured tubal ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

Studdiford Criteria are used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy. This criterion involves:

 

  1. Ensuring that both fallopian tubes and ovaries are normal with no signs of injury.
  2. Confirming that no utero-peritoneal fistula is present.
  3. Verifying that the placenta is attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface.

 

These criteria help distinguish primary abdominal pregnancy from other types of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 219, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

choices.text: Decreased number of Lactobacilli
Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium
pH > 6.8
Epithelial thinning

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

 

  • Vaginal epithelium increases the metabolism of glycogen in pregnancy.
  • It leads to decrease in pH and makes the vaginal epithelium more acidic
  • This is because of increased lactobacilli

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased number of Lactobacilli: The number of lactobacilli are increased in the reproductive age group especially in pregnancy

 

Option C. pH > 6.8: Vaginal pH in pregnancy is acidic

 

 

Option D. Epithelial thinning: Estrogen increases the vaginal thickness in pregnancy. The vagina becomes thin in the absence of estrogen (like in menopause)

 

Educational Objective:

 

During pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium increases glycogen metabolism, leading to a more acidic environment that promotes the growth of Lactobacilli and helps protect against infections.

 

Ref: Page no 20, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose dependent
MgSO4 is continued upto 24 hours after delivery or last attack of seizure
It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP
In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding MgSO4 is false? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

 

The statement that MgSO4 has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP is false. MgSO4 is indeed effective in preventing seizures, particularly in the context of eclampsia, due to its action on the cerebral cortex. However, it does not lower blood pressure. Instead, its primary role is as an anticonvulsant and a tocolytic (uterine relaxant), not as an antihypertensive agent. MgSO4’s role in managing hypertension is minimal, and it is not used specifically for blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose dependent: This statement is true. MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic to relax the uterus in a dose-dependent manner. It helps in managing preterm labor by relaxing uterine contractions.

 

Option B. MgSO4 is continued up to 24 hours after delivery or the last attack of seizure: This statement is true. Magnesium sulfate is continued for 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure to prevent recurrence of seizures and to provide adequate time for stabilization.

 

Option D. In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but the maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function: This statement is true. In patients with renal failure, the loading dose of MgSO4 can be given, but the maintenance dose should be carefully adjusted due to impaired excretion of magnesium, which could lead to toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is used for preventing seizures in eclampsia and causes uterine relaxation but does not lower blood pressure.

 

Ref: Page no 1867, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Wait and watch for 4 weeks
Repeat TVS after one week
Serum HCG levels

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. Crown Rump Length was 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks on TVS. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat TVS after one week

 

In the case described, the patient has a gestational sac and a crown-rump length (CRL) of 5 mm, with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks based on transvaginal sonography (TVS). The guidelines for assessing early pregnancy viability are:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a mean sac diameter (MSD) ≥ 25 mm indicates an anembryonic pregnancy.
  • Absence of cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm indicates a non-viable pregnancy.

 

In this scenario, the CRL is 5 mm, which is below the threshold where the absence of cardiac activity would indicate a non-viable pregnancy (≥ 7 mm). There is no mention of cardiac activity in the current ultrasound findings, so it is crucial to monitor the pregnancy further before making any conclusions.

 

The best course of action is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to check for the presence of cardiac activity and further development of the embryo. This approach allows for a more accurate assessment of the viability of the pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch for 4 weeks: Waiting for 4 weeks without further evaluation could delay necessary medical intervention and is not recommended for timely assessment of pregnancy viability.

 

Option C. Serum HCG levels: While measuring serum HCG levels can provide some information about the progression of the pregnancy, it is less specific than ultrasound for determining viability, particularly in the context of assessing cardiac activity.

 

Option D. Medical intervention: Immediate medical intervention is not warranted at this stage without further evidence. The repeat ultrasound will provide more clarity on whether intervention is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy with a CRL of less than 7 mm and no documented cardiac activity, the best approach is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to reassess for the presence of cardiac activity and viability of the pregnancy.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 645

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Saline infusion sonography

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.
    • Endometrial cavity lesions like polyps, adhesions
    • Tubal patency in infertility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Hysteroscopy appears like this image. Using fluid media to distend the uterine cavity, a hysteroscope can visualize the inside of the uterine cavity.

 

 

Option B. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography: This is an ultrasound-based investigation, wherein saline is injected in the uterine cavity and this helps detect intra-uterine space occupying lesions and appears like this:

 

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound: This appears like this:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is an X-ray procedure used to delineate uterine anomalies, identify endometrial cavity lesions, and assess tubal patency in cases of infertility.

 

Ref: Page no 588, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Pap smear
Visual inspection with iodine

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

  • Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is a better first-line investigation since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer.
  • Both diabetes and hypertension are risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma hence endometrial sampling would be the more appropriate test as compared to tests for cervical cancer screening.
  • Endometrial sampling is indicated in a woman with post-menopausal bleeding with the endometrial thickness is > 4 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: A pap smear should be done in all women complaining of post menopausal women with a normal looking cervix and a cervical biopsy for all women with a cervical growth but in this question, based on risk factors, we are more worried about endometrial cancer and hence endometrial sampling is a better option.

 

Option B. Visual inspection with iodine: This is not the preferred option and even if cervical cancer screening is warranted, a pap smear or HPV is better.

 

Option C. Colposcopy: This is indicated if there is any cytological abnormality on the pap smear

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Ref: Page no 560, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

choices.text: Metronidazole
Fluconazole
Clindamycin

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of pregnant woman with bacterial vaginosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis (BV) in pregnant women. This choice is based on its efficacy in addressing the anaerobic bacterial overgrowth that characterizes BV. It is generally prescribed as 200 mg three times daily for 7 days during pregnancy. While Clindamycin is also used for BV and can be an alternative, Metronidazole remains the preferred treatment due to its effectiveness and established safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: This drug is used for the treatment of fungal infections like candidiasis, not bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option C. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for BV, especially if Metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, Metronidazole is typically preferred.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: This antibiotic is generally used for various bacterial infections but is not the first choice for BV. It is not typically used for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents to the emergency department 20 days after sustaining minor trauma to his face with a piece of wood while working. He initially had mild pain and swelling, but over the past few days, his symptoms worsened with facial asymmetry, swelling, and a dark discoloration around his nose and eye. A CT scan shows clear sinuses but multiple subcutaneous nodules. Microscopic examination of tissue sections are positive for PAS and Gomori methenamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mucormycosis


Mucormycosis, also known as phycomycosis, is a severe fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with uncontrolled diabetes. The infection often begins in the nasal and paranasal sinuses and can rapidly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, and brain due to the fungus’s propensity to invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and tissue necrosis. Clinical features include a black necrotic mass in the nasal cavity, facial asymmetry, and, in severe cases, involvement of the eye and brain. Diagnosis is confirmed through tissue biopsy showing fungal hyphae with special stains like PAS and Gomori methenamine silver. Treatment involves aggressive surgical debridement and antifungal therapy, such as Amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth, usually following a break in the skin. It does not involve black necrosis, tissue invasion, or the characteristic findings seen in mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: This condition is an infection of the tissues around the eye, usually secondary to sinusitis, characterized by pain, swelling, and decreased eye movement. It does not cause the rapid necrosis and vascular invasion seen in mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma is a slow-growing skin cancer that typically appears as a pearly nodule or ulcerated lesion on sun-exposed areas. It lacks the acute infectious nature and does not present with the systemic signs or rapid progression associated with mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Mucormycosis is a rapidly progressing fungal infection affecting immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with uncontrolled diabetes. It is characterized by tissue necrosis, often involving the nasal cavity, orbit, and brain. Early recognition, surgical debridement, and antifungal therapy are crucial in managing this life-threatening condition

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis from the given clinical image?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterocervical prolapse

 

The clinical image shows a case of uterocervical prolapse. This condition is common in elderly women due to weak pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism, leading to a downward displacement of the uterus and cervix into the vaginal canal.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Uterocervical Prolapse: The uterus and cervix descend into the vaginal canal, often visualized clearly as in the image provided.
  • Differential Diagnoses:
    • Cervical carcinoma: Typically presents with a growth or ulceration on the cervix, which is not seen in this image.
    • Uterine inversion: Characterized by the uterus turning inside out, where the cervical rim would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion.
    • Fibroid polyp: Would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up in its anatomical position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: The image does not show any growth or ulceration, which are typical features of cervical carcinoma.

 

Option B. Uterine inversion: In uterine inversion, the cervix would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. Fibroid polyp: A fibroid polyp would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical image showing clear visualization of the cervix along with the prolapsed uterus indicates uterocervical prolapse, a condition often seen in elderly women due to weakened pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg548, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 224

choices.text: Congenital heart defects

questions.text: On finding a congenital heart block in a fetus which of the following conditions would you evaluate for in the mother? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SLE

 

Congenital heart block (CHB) in a fetus is often associated with maternal autoimmune conditions, particularly Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). This condition is related to the presence of maternal antibodies against the SS-A (Ro) or SS-B (La) antigens. These antibodies can cross the placenta and affect the fetal heart, leading to congenital heart block. Therefore, if a congenital heart block is detected in a fetus, it is essential to evaluate the mother for SLE.

 

Neonatal lupus erythematosus, a subtype of lupus erythematosus, is caused by the transplacental passage of these maternal antibodies. The most frequent clinical manifestations in the neonate include congenital heart block and cutaneous lesions. Fetal echocardiography is recommended between 18 and 26 weeks of gestation in pregnancies where these antibodies are present to monitor for congenital heart block.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APLA syndrome: Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) is associated with increased risks of miscarriages, intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), and preterm births. However, it is not specifically associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Option B. Congenital heart defects: Women with certain congenital cardiac defects may have an increased chance of giving birth to children with similar defects, such as Marfan syndrome, aortic stenosis, ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), and coarctation of the aorta. However, these conditions are not directly linked to congenital heart block caused by maternal antibodies.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemias, such as thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and hereditary spherocytosis, are inherited conditions but are not associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital heart block (CHB) in a fetus is associated with maternal antibodies to SS-A (Ro) or SS-B (La), commonly seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 722

choices.text: Colposcopy and biopsy
Follow-up after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix and no obvious macroscopic growth. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conization

 

  • Carcinoma in situ is Stage 0 Cancer.
  • It means it involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without invasion of the basement membrane.
  • This should be followed by a conization as the woman is 30 years old and conization will provide us with a biopsy specimen as well as be curative
  • If family is complete/ elderly patient, simple hysterectomy should be done

 

Treatment for Different stages of cervical cancer

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: While effective, it is more invasive and typically reserved for those who have completed childbearing or for older patients.

 

Option C. Colposcopy and biopsy: This is used for further evaluation but is not the definitive treatment for CIS when the diagnosis is already confirmed.

 

Option D. Follow-up after 6 months: Follow-up without intervention is not appropriate for CIS due to the risk of progression to invasive cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young woman diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix, conization is the recommended next step, providing both diagnostic and therapeutic benefits.

 

Ref: FIGO Revised Staging of Cervical Cancer, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th Edition, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 8th edition page367,

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

  • Intense vaginal itching and foul-smelling greenish discharge are suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.
  • Strawberry like appearance of the cervix helps in establishing the diagnosis.
  • On vaginal smear, flagellated organism (T. vaginalis is seen)

 

Other Options:

 

Best understood by this table given below

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling, frothy yellowish-green discharge and a strawberry-like appearance of the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

choices.text: Loss of knee jerk
Reduced muscle tone

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulfate. What is the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of knee jerk

 

  • Therapeutic range: The therapeutic range of magnesium for the prevention of seizures in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.
  • Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of DTRs, specifically the knee jerk reflex. This occurs when plasma magnesium levels reach 7-10 mEq/L.
  • Respiratory depression: When plasma magnesium levels reach 10-12 mEq/L, respiratory depression occurs. Beyond 12 mEq/L, respiratory paralysis and respiratory arrest can occur.
  • Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest can happen if serum magnesium levels exceed 25 mEq/L.
  • Monitoring: A patient on magnesium sulfate is monitored for toxicity by checking clinical signs, including DTRs, urine output, and respiratory rate.
  • Treatment of toxicity: Treatment for magnesium sulfate toxicity involves administering calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (1g intravenously) and discontinuing magnesium sulfate, which usually reverses mild to moderate respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotension: Hypotension is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: Respiratory depression occurs at higher magnesium levels (10-12 mEq/L), after the loss of knee jerk reflex.

 

Option D. Reduced muscle tone: Reduced muscle tone is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity and is less specific than the loss of DTRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition page 759

questions.text: Based on the patient's history of relapsing, remitting, mildly itchy erythematous plaques on the scalp, sacral area, and knees, along with joint pain and the displayed nail changes in the image below, what would be your diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

 

The diagnosis in this patient showing nail pitting, oil drop sign, and salmon patches in fingernails is psoriasis.

 

  • The nail changes shown in the image, such as nail pitting and onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed), along with the patient's history of itchy erythematous plaques and joint pain, are characteristic of psoriasis.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adult-onset Still's disease:

 

This systemic inflammatory condition typically presents with a salmon-pink rash, fever, and arthritis but is not typically associated with the nail changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Pachyonychia congenita:

 

A rare genetic condition affecting the nails, characterized by thickened nails (pachyonychia) as seen in the image below.

 

 

Option D. Lichen planus:

 

This condition can affect the nails, causing thinning and splitting, and it can also lead to lacy white lesions on the mucous membranes (Wickham's striae), but the nail changes in the image are more characteristic of psoriasis, and lichen planus doesn’t commonly cause joint pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When presented with nail pitting, onycholysis, erythematous plaques with scales on common sites such as the scalp, sacral area, and knees, along with joint pain, consider psoriasis as a likely diagnosis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.4-35.6

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Anaplasma phagocytophilum

questions.text: The inclusion body Rickettsial morula is found in neutrophils during infection caused by? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterium known to cause the disease tick-borne fever (TBF) in domestic ruminants in Ixodes ricinus-infested areas in northern Europe. This organism infects granulocytes, particularly neutrophils, leading to the formation of characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies known as morulae.

 

During an infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum, light microscopy of blood smears taken in the initial fever period can often suffice for diagnosis. When these blood smears are stained with May-Grünwald Giemsa, the organisms appear as blue cytoplasmic inclusions within the neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: This bacterium causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which does not typically involve the formation of morulae in neutrophils. Instead, it causes endothelial cell infection leading to vasculitis.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: The causative agent of Mediterranean spotted fever, also does not typically form morulae in neutrophils. Like R. rickettsii, it primarily infects endothelial cells.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: This bacterium causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) and forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils. This distinguishes it from Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which targets neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes the formation of Rickettsial morulae in neutrophils, whereas Ehrlichia chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes.

 

Mnemonic "GAME": Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis.

choices.text: 70% amorphous 30% crystalline
70% crystalline 30% amorphous
Only 70% amorphous
D Other name of NPH insulin

questions.text: Composition of Lente insulin is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 70% crystalline 30% amorphous

 

Lente insulin has two components in it:

 

  • Ultralente insulin, which is water insoluble insulin zinc suspension with large crystalline particles (70%), it has a long half-life.
  • Semilente insulin, which is amorphous, has smaller particles and is short acting. (30%)
  • These two components are mixed in this 7:3 ratio, making Lente insulin intermediate acting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70% amorphous 30% crystalline: This is incorrect as the amorphous part makes up only 30% of the composition in Lente insulin.

 

Option C. Only 70% amorphous: This is incorrect because Lente insulin is a mixture of both crystalline and amorphous components, not just one type.

 

Option D. Other name of NPH insulin: This is incorrect. Lente insulin and NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) insulin are different formulations. NPH insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin that is a suspension of insulin with protamine and zinc, which prolongs its action, but it is not referred to as Lente insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lente insulin is composed of 70% crystalline (long-acting) and 30% amorphous (short-acting) insulin, making it an intermediate-acting insulin formulation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with facial pain, swelling, and congestion following a recent sinus infection that has not improved with antibiotics. He complains of increased pressure and pain localized around his affected sinus. The physician decides to order an X-ray to better evaluate the extent of sinus involvement and any potential complications such as sinusitis or fracture. A Waters' view X-ray is performed to assess the sinuses and facial structures. The physician explains the importance of this specific view for visualizing the sinuses. Which sinus is best visualized in a Waters’ view X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Maxillary sinus


The Waters' view, also known as the occipitomental view, is specifically designed to best visualize the maxillary sinuses. In this view, the X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line, projecting the petrous bones below the maxillary sinuses, allowing clear visualization. This positioning makes it the preferred imaging method for evaluating maxillary sinus pathology, such as sinusitis or fractures. Other structures, including the frontal and sphenoid sinuses, can also be seen, but the maxillary sinuses are highlighted the most prominently in this view.

 

 

Other Options:


Option B. Frontal sinus: Although the frontal sinus can be seen in a Waters' view, it is not the primary sinus visualized, and other views, like the Caldwell view, are more effective for frontal sinus assessment.

 

Option C. Ethmoid sinus: The ethmoid sinuses are difficult to see clearly in the Waters' view due to their anatomical positioning and overlapping structures. They are better visualized with a coronal CT scan or other specialized imaging techniques.

 

Option D. Sphenoid sinus: The sphenoid sinus may be visualized in the Waters' view only if the film is taken with the mouth open, but it is not the best view for this sinus. Other imaging techniques, such as lateral or submental vertex views, are preferred for sphenoid sinus evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:


The Waters’ view X-ray is primarily used to visualize the maxillary sinuses due to its specific angulation, making it an essential diagnostic tool in assessing maxillary sinusitis, fractures, and other pathologies. It projects the petrous bones below the sinuses, providing the clearest view of the maxillary region compared to other sinuses.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

 

The patient presents with sensory loss, limb weakness, and specific neurological findings that are indicative of subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Sensory Loss and Weakness of Limbs: This suggests a neurological disorder affecting the peripheral and central nervous systems.
  2. Angular Stomatitis: This is often associated with vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin B12.
  3. Loss of Proprioception and Vibration Sensation: This is characteristic of posterior column involvement, which is seen in subacute combined degeneration.
  4. UMN Type of Lower Limb Weakness: Upper motor neuron signs (UMN) such as spasticity and exaggerated reflexes, except for the absent ankle reflex, are indicative of corticospinal tract involvement.
  5. Absent Ankle Reflex: This, along with UMN signs, is a classic feature of subacute combined degeneration of the cord.

 

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord: This condition is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to demyelination of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts. This results in a combination of sensory ataxia, spasticity, and other upper motor neuron signs, except for the absent ankle reflex which indicates peripheral neuropathy.

 

Additional Findings:

 

  • Angular Stomatitis: Points towards a vitamin deficiency.
  • Babinski Positivity with Absent Ankle Jerk: This combination is specifically associated with subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to B12 deficiency. Other conditions like cauda equina syndrome or Friedreich ataxia could present similarly, but the presence of angular stomatitis and the described neurological findings strongly support subacute combined degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Cord Compression: This would typically present with radicular pain and possibly more pronounced lower motor neuron signs below the level of compression, not the UMN signs described here.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): ALS involves both UMN and LMN signs but does not typically present with sensory loss or specific vitamin deficiency signs like angular stomatitis.

 

Option C. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS can present with varied neurological signs, but it does not typically present with angular stomatitis or the classic combination of absent ankle reflex with UMN signs seen in subacute combined degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with sensory loss, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflex, along with other signs of vitamin deficiency like angular stomatitis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patella fracture

 

The X-ray provided shows a clear fracture line through the patella, indicating a patella fracture.

 

In the provided image, the presence of a sharp, discontinuous line through the patella confirms the diagnosis of a patella fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemarthrosis: This condition would cause swelling in the joint but would not show a fracture line. The X-ray does not indicate swelling without a fracture, ruling out hemarthrosis.

 

 

Option C. Bipartite patella: This is a congenital condition where the patella is naturally in two parts. It shows smooth, well-defined borders unlike the jagged edges seen in fractures. The X-ray here clearly shows a fracture line, not a bipartite patella.

 

 

Option D. Ligament injury: Ligament injuries do not show up on X-rays as they involve soft tissues. Thus, this option is not relevant to the findings on the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patella fracture can be identified on an X-ray by a distinct fracture line through the patella, differentiating it from other conditions like hemarthrosis, bipartite patella, and ligament injuries.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma showing hypercellular areas (Antoni A), including Verocay bodies, as well as looser (hypocellular) areas, myxoid regions (Antoni B).

 

 

 

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached to the nerve but can be separated from it. Tumors form firm, gray masses that may have areas of cystic and xanthomatous change.

 

On microscopic examination tumors show a mixture of two growth patterns:

 

  • In the Antoni A pattern of growth, elongated cells with cytoplasmic processes are arranged in fascicles in areas of moderate to high cellularity and scant stromal matrix; the “nuclear-free zones” of processes that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies.
  • In the Antoni B pattern of growth, the tumor is less densely cellular (hypocellular) and consists of a loose meshwork of cells, microcysts and myxoid stroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leiomyoma: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors that do not typically present with the histological features observed in the provided image, such as Verocay bodies or the Antoni A/B patterns seen in schwannomas.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin, often characterized by spindle-shaped cells and cross-striations on histology. It lacks the distinctive Antoni A and B patterns seen in schwannomas.

 

Option D. Fibromatosis: Fibromatosis refers to a group of benign fibrous tissue proliferations that are locally aggressive but lack the encapsulated, well-circumscribed nature of schwannomas. The histology of fibromatosis does not show the Antoni A and B patterns or Verocay bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannomas are benign nerve sheath tumors with distinct Antoni A and B growth patterns, including Verocay bodies. These features, along with the clinical presentation, are key to the diagnosis.

 

Clinical presentations: 

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no - 2595

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

questions.text:
What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Disrupted cell membrane
  2. Induces inflammation
  3. Swelling of the cell
  4. Can be seen physiologically
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Necrosis is a form of cell injury that results in the premature death of cells in living tissue by autolysis. The following are the key characteristics of necrosis:

 

1. Disrupted cell membrane: Necrosis is characterized by the loss of cell membrane integrity, leading to the uncontrolled release of cellular contents into the extracellular space.

 

2. Induces inflammation: The release of cellular contents into the surrounding tissue causes an inflammatory response. This is a hallmark of necrosis, as the body reacts to the injury.

 

3. Swelling of the cell: In necrosis, cells typically swell and eventually rupture due to the loss of membrane integrity and the influx of water and ions.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Necrosis is never physiological: it always occurs as a result of pathological conditions. Unlike apoptosis, which is a programmed and regulated form of cell death, necrosis is unregulated and is usually detrimental to the organism.

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

FEATURES OF NECROSIS

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents due to persistent nasal congestion, snoring, and mouth breathing, which have been ongoing for over a year. The parents report that she often sleeps with her mouth open and has difficulty breathing through her nose. They have also noticed that her face appears elongated, and she has a dull expression with an open-mouth posture most of the time. On examination, the child exhibits dental crowding with prominent upper teeth and a high arched palate. Based on the clinical findings, the physician suspects a chronic condition affecting her facial structure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenoid facies


The characteristic features of adenoid facies, a condition resulting from chronic adenoid hypertrophy. This condition is marked by an elongated face with a dull expression, an open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, a hitched-up upper lip, and crowded prominent upper teeth. Other distinguishing features include a high arched hard palate and a pinched-in nose. Chronic mouth breathing due to enlarged adenoids can alter facial growth, leading to these characteristic features. Management of adenoid hypertrophy is crucial to prevent further impact on facial development and respiratory function.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Cushing syndrome: Cushing syndrome is characterized by a rounded "moon face," truncal obesity, and other systemic signs related to excessive cortisol levels, which are not seen in this patient. It does not cause the elongated face or open-mouth posture typical of adenoid facies.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome presents with distinct facial features, including a flat nasal bridge, epicanthal folds, and a protruding tongue, none of which are present in the patient shown in the image. The facial appearance in Down syndrome differs significantly from that of adenoid facies.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Although allergic rhinitis can cause mouth breathing and nasal congestion, it does not typically lead to the characteristic facial features of adenoid facies, such as an elongated face, high arched palate, or crowded upper teeth. Allergic rhinitis primarily affects nasal passages without altering facial structure significantly.

 

Educational Objective:


Adenoid facies is characterized by an elongated face, open-mouth posture, crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose, often resulting from chronic adenoid hypertrophy. This condition highlights the impact of prolonged nasal obstruction on facial development and underscores the importance of early recognition and management to prevent permanent facial changes and respiratory complications.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Yogurt

 

Yogurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance among the options listed. This is because yogurt contains live bacteria, specifically lactobacilli, which help to break down lactose. This fermentation process reduces the lactose content significantly, making yogurt easier to digest for individuals with lactase deficiency. Additionally, these bacteria can contribute to the production of some lactase enzyme, aiding in the digestion of any remaining lactose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skimmed Milk: Contains nearly the same amount of lactose as regular milk, just with less fat. It is likely to cause symptoms in someone with lactose intolerance.

 

Option B. Condensed Milk: Even higher in lactose because it is milk that has been concentrated by removing water. High lactose content makes it more likely to cause intolerance symptoms.

 

Option C. Ice-cream: Typically high in lactose because it is made from cream and milk, both of which are high in lactose. Ice cream can also contain mix-ins and flavorings that increase the lactose content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yogurt contains lactobacillus, that helps in lactase production and also low lactose levels.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastroenterology/Diarrhea/chap 471

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in chelation of heavy metals: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oximes

 

Oximes, like pralidoxime, are specifically used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates and are not effective for heavy metal chelation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): Used for chelation of heavy metals such as lead and cadmium.

 

Option B. B.A.L (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): Used for chelation of heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, and mercury.

 

Option C. Desferrioxamine: Specifically used for chelation of iron.

 

Educational Objective :

questions.text: Identify the seeds shown in the image below: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nigella sativa 

 

The seeds shown in the given image are of the plant Nigella sativa. 

 

Other names - black cumin or kalonji.

 

Method of action - Sativa modulates the neuronal release of GABA, glycine, aspartate and glutamate on cultured cortical neurons and also possesses a potent central nervous system (CNS) sedative and analgesic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tropicana canna: This option is incorrect as Tropicana canna refers to a type of plant known for its large, colorful leaves and flowers, not for its seeds.

 

 

Option C. Datura seeds: Incorrect, as Datura seeds are typically flatter and have a distinct shape compared to Nigella sativa. Datura is also known for its toxic properties and is used in traditional medicine with caution.

 

 

Option D. Opium seeds: Incorrect. Opium seeds likely refer to poppy seeds, which are smaller and have a different texture and appearance compared to Nigella sativa seeds.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nigella sativa, or black cumin, is not only recognized for its unique seed appearance but also for its significant medicinal properties, including sedative and analgesic effects on the central nervous system.

questions.text: In which of the following phenomenon, Cell in cell appearance is seen? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Entosis

 

Cell in cell appearance is seen in Entosis.

 

Entosis is a form of cell death that occurs when one cell inserts itself into the neighboring cell, which results in the ultimate death of the invading cell. This creates a characteristic cell-in-cell (CIC. pattern. It plays a physiological role in the elimination of cells detached from a surface.

 

NOTE: Emperipolesis vs Entosis

 

Emperipolesis is a cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed. This process occurs in various cell types, including immune cells and cancer cells, and is thought to play a role in cell-to-cell communication and immune surveillance. In emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell after a certain period of time.

 

 

Entosis on the other hand, is a cellular process in which one cell actively engulfs and digests another cell. This process occurs primarily in epithelial cells and is thought to play a role in tissue homeostasis and elimination of damaged or excess cells. In entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell's lysosomes.

 

In summary, the main difference between emperipolesis and entosis is that in emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell, while in entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrosis: Necrosis is a form of cell death characterized by uncontrolled cellular breakdown due to injury or disease. It does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance and is marked by cell swelling, membrane rupture, and inflammation.

 

Option B. Apoptosis: Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death involving cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, but it does not result in a cell-in-cell appearance. Instead, apoptotic cells are typically engulfed and removed by phagocytes.

 

Option C. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a regulated form of necrosis or inflammatory cell death that is triggered by certain death receptors. Like necrosis, it does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cell-in-cell appearance is characteristic of entosis, where one cell engulfs and digests another, distinguishing it from other forms of cell death.

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image below: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abrasion

 

The given image shows the superficial injury and is not penetrating the full thickness of the epidermis, bleeding is also not seen, all these indicates towards abrasion.

 

Abrasion

 

  • Abrasions are superficial injuries of the skin and visceral linings in the body, resulting in a break in the continuity of tissue.
  • It does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis.
  • Only epidermis (mostly partial epidermis) is involved.
  • No bleeding.
  • No scar formation.
  • All abrasions are simple hurt except corneal abrasions (impairs vision and hence a grievous hurt).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laceration is a deep wound produced by the tearing of soft body tissue. This type of wound is often irregular and jagged.

 

Option C. Bruise is caused by a direct blow to the body that can cause damage to the surface of the skin and to deeper tissues. It causes rupture of capillaries of the skin leading to the bruise

 

Option D. Imprint or impact abrasion happens when large force is applied over lesser period of time, also results in crushing epithelium eg.: Tyre mark, recoil abrasion, radiator grill mark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abrasions are superficial injuries involving only the epidermis, with no bleeding and no scar formation, and are typically simple hurts except for corneal abrasions.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the targets of their actions: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1
 

  • Trastuzumab is used in HER2/neu positive breast cancers.
  • Infliximab is anti-TNFα monoclonal antibody used in the management of Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Sirolimus acts by inhibiting the progression of cell cycle from G1 to S phase by blocking mTOR. It is used in the prevention of transplant rejection.
  • Imatinib is a BCR-ABL inhibitor that is used in the treatment of CML.
     

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Secondary arrest after progression of labor
Prolonged active phase of labor
Prolonged latent phase/primary arrest of labor
Normal labor in a primigravida

questions.text: The following graph represents the stages of labor. Which statement accurately describes the scenario depicted in Graph C? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Secondary arrest after labor progression

 

Graph C shows an arrest in the active phase of labor, also known as secondary arrest. This occurs when there is a halt in cervical dilation after initial progress has been made. According to Friedman’s research, the first stage of labor consists of the latent phase, where contractions are irregular and cervical dilation is slow, and the active phase, where the rate of cervical dilation increases significantly. If cervical dilation stops for more than 2 hours during the active phase, it is considered a secondary arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prolonged active phase of labor - This occurs when the active phase of labor progresses slower than expected, but it does not imply a complete arrest in dilation.

 

Option c. Prolonged latent phase or primary arrest of labor - This describes a slow progression or halt in the early, latent phase of labor, not during the active phase as shown in Graph C.

 

Option d. Normal labor in a first-time mother - Normal labor would not show a secondary arrest in the active phase as depicted in the graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graph C depicts secondary arrest in the active phase of labor, where there is a cessation of cervical dilation after initial progress

questions.text: Which of the following proteins of human papilloma virus inactivates Rb gene? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E7

 

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with several cancers, including cervical cancer. HPV has two key oncoproteins, E6 and E7, that play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of cancer by inactivating tumor suppressor proteins.

 

E7 protein binds to and inactivates the Rb (Retinoblastoma) gene, which is a crucial tumor suppressor that controls cell cycle progression. By inactivating Rb, E7 disrupts the regulation of the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation, a hallmark of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6: Targets and degrades p53 but does not inactivate Rb. E6 promotes the degradation of p53, leading to the loss of its tumor suppressor functions, such as apoptosis and DNA repair.

 

Option C. L1: L1 is a major capsid protein of HPV involved in the assembly of the viral particle but does not have a role in inactivating tumor suppressor genes.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is a minor capsid protein involved in viral genome packaging and entry into host cells but does not inactivate tumor suppressor genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E7 protein of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the Rb gene, leading to disruption of the cell cycle and contributing to the development of cancer.

 

HPV Oncoproteins:

 

 

L1 protein is useful for making vaccine for HPV. (recent INICET ques)

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleuritis with/without pleural effusion.

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion is the most common pulmonary manifestation in patients with SLE. This condition reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of SLE, which frequently affects serous membranes including the pleura. Pleural involvement in SLE typically presents as an exudative pleural effusion, often characterized by pleuritic pain and effusion that can be detected by physical examination and imaging studies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shrinking lung syndrome: is very rare occurring in 1% of patients. Some association with Anti-Ro/La antibodies seen. No correlation between disease activity, symptoms and antibodies.

 

Option B. Intra Alveolar hemorrhage and D. Interstitial inflammation: are not the most common presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion stands out as the most frequent pulmonary complication in SLE due to the disease’s propensity to inflame serous membranes. Accurate diagnosis and effective management of SLE and its pulmonary manifestations are crucial for improving quality of life and reducing morbidity in affected patients.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever, night sweats, and neck swelling. The biopsy of swelling showed a starry sky appearance. What is the most likely genetic abnormality seen in this case? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MYC gene

 

The given clinical scenario and the classical histopathological finding of starry sky appearance suggest the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma and the most likely genetic abnormality is the translocation of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. Typical cytogenetic abnormalities is t(8;14) and t(8;22) involving MYC gene on chromosome 8, with overexpression of MYC protein having transforming activity.

 

Burkitt lymphoma is very aggressive (very high Ki67) but responds well to intensive chemotherapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RAS: Mutations in the RAS gene are associated with various cancers, including some leukemias and solid tumors, but not specifically with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option C. BCR-ABL: This genetic abnormality is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option D. p53: Mutations in the p53 gene are common in many types of cancer but are not the defining feature of Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by the t(8;14) translocation involving the MYC gene, which leads to the overexpression of the MYC protein, driving the aggressive nature of the disease. The starry sky appearance on histopathology is a key diagnostic feature.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1123

choices.text: A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2
A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

questions.text: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice used for each? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

  1. Vancomycin is Drug of Choice for Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) – It acts by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis and is a bactericidal drug.
  2. Metronidazole drug of choice against anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  3. Meropenem is used in infections caused by Klebsiella. Klebsiella is known to produce ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta Lactamases). Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL. Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.
  4. Penicillin like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice for infections caused by MRSA.
  • Penicillins like amoxicillin and ampicillin are used for Haemophilus influenzae infections.
  • Meropenem is used for infections caused by Klebsiella, particularly ESBL-producing strains.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the feet
Vertical nystagmus towards the head
Rotary nystagmus towards the opposite ear

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of dizziness and imbalance that worsen when he moves his head quickly. To assess his vestibular function, the physician decides to perform a caloric test, which involves irrigating the ear with different temperatures of water while the patient lies supine with his head elevated at 30 degrees. The physician explains that this test helps in evaluating the function of the vestibular system. During the test, cold water is used for irrigation. What type of nystagmus is expected when cold water is used for irrigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side


In the caloric test, cold water irrigation causes horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side due to the inhibition of the vestibular system on the side of the irrigation. The test, often known as the Fitzgerald-Hallpike test or bithermal caloric test, involves placing the patient supine with the head tilted 30 degrees forward to align the horizontal semicircular canal vertically. This positioning allows irrigation to directly affect the lateral semicircular canal, inducing nystagmus. The mnemonic "COWS" (Cold-Opposite, Warm-Same) helps remember that cold water induces nystagmus towards the opposite side, while warm water causes nystagmus towards the same side.

 

 

 

Other Options:


Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the feet: Vertical nystagmus is not typically associated with caloric testing, which primarily stimulates the lateral semicircular canals and produces horizontal nystagmus rather than vertical.

 

Option C. Vertical nystagmus towards the head: Vertical nystagmus does not occur during caloric testing, as this test specifically stimulates the horizontal semicircular canal, leading to horizontal nystagmus.

 

Option D. Rotary nystagmus towards the opposite ear: Rotary or torsional nystagmus is related to vertical semicircular canal involvement or central vestibular causes, not the horizontal semicircular canal stimulated in the caloric test.

 

Educational Objective:


The caloric test uses temperature-induced stimulation of the lateral semicircular canal to assess vestibular function, with cold water causing horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side and warm water causing it towards the same side. This response pattern helps evaluate peripheral vestibular function and diagnose vestibular disorders.

questions.text: Indicated structure gives origin to which of the following fiber (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dentato-rubral

 

The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is the largest and most lateral of these nuclei. It is involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers. These fibers project from the dentate nucleus to the red nucleus in the midbrain, playing a crucial role in the coordination of motor movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-rubral: Incorrect because while it involves the cerebellum and red nucleus, the correct specific term for the fiber originating from the dentate nucleus is "dentato-rubral."

 

Option B. Cerebello-reticul: Incorrect because this option refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the reticular formation, not specifically involving the dentate nucleus.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibul: Incorrect because this refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation, not related to the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers, which project to the red nucleus and are crucial for motor coordination.

questions.text: Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked with the question mark in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior colliculus

 

The highlighted muscle is the medial rectus, which is supplied by the oculomotor nerve. The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve is situated at the level of the superior colliculus. The oculomotor nerve arises from a nuclear complex that includes the oculomotor nucleus and Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus. The oculomotor nucleus is comprised of several groups of large motor neurons that innervate the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus in dorsoventral order. Additionally, a column of cells located medially innervates the contralateral superior rectus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior olivary: This is part of the auditory pathway and has no involvement in eye muscle control.

 

Option B. Inferior colliculus: Also part of the auditory pathway, located in the midbrain but not involved in motor control of eye movements.

 

Option D. Fascial colliculus: This term is likely a typographical error for "facial colliculus," which refers to a structure in the brainstem associated with the facial nerve, not the oculomotor nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve, responsible for innervating the medial rectus muscle among others, is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain.
