This is crucial for understanding the neural control of eye movements, particularly in how various components of the eye are coordinated for proper visual alignment and focus.

choices.text: Laparoscopic tubal ligation

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopic tubal ligation

 

Contraceptive methods can be classified into temporary (reversible) and permanent (irreversible) methods.

 

  • Permanent Methods (Irreversible):
    • Laparoscopic Tubal Ligation: This is a surgical procedure where the fallopian tubes are cut, tied, or sealed to prevent pregnancy permanently. It is considered an irreversible method of contraception as it is intended to be a permanent solution for women who do not wish to have more children.
  • Temporary Methods (Reversible):
    • Copper-T (Intrauterine Device - IUD): A long-term but reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.
    • Implanon (Subdermal Contraceptive Implant): A long-term reversible method that can be removed to restore fertility.
    • LNG-IUD (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine Device): Another long-term reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent (irreversible) method of contraception.

 

Ref: Page no 611, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Rees and Ecker diluting fluid is used in? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RBC Pipette

 

Rees and Ecker's solution is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC pipette for performing platelet counts. This diluting fluid is formulated to preserve the platelets while preventing their clumping, allowing for accurate counting under a microscope.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wintrobe tube: This is a tube used for measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and not related to the use of Rees and Ecker's solution.

 

Option B. WBC Pipette: A WBC pipette is used for counting white blood cells, typically with a different diluting fluid that is specific for leukocytes i. e Turk's fluid.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin pipette: This pipette is used for hemoglobinometry, which involves measuring the concentration of hemoglobin in the blood, and does not involve Rees and Ecker's solution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rees and Ecker's solution is used with the RBC pipette to accurately count platelets by preventing clumping and preserving the cells for microscopic examination.

 

Mnemonic:

 

Rees - RBCs (R-R)

questions.text: Identify the condition for which Dohlman’s procedure is used: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Zenker's diverticulum

 

Dohlman's procedure is a surgical technique primarily used to treat Zenker's diverticulum. Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms at the junction of the esophagus and pharynx, causing swallowing difficulties, regurgitation, and aspiration. Dohlman's procedure involves endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to alleviate the obstruction and diverticulum formation. This method is favored for its minimal invasiveness and effectiveness in managing the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is treated with a diverticulectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the diverticulum. This congenital anomaly of the small intestine often presents with bleeding, inflammation, or obstruction.

 

Option C. Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia, a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, is typically treated with laparotomy or laparoscopic surgery and subsequent hernia repair. This condition involves abdominal organs herniating into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Menetrier's disease: Menetrier's disease, a rare disorder characterized by hypertrophic gastric folds and protein-losing gastropathy, does not have a specific surgical procedure for treatment. Management often includes supportive care, protein supplements, and medications such as proton pump inhibitors or cetuximab.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dohlman's procedure is specifically used to treat Zenker's diverticulum by endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to relieve symptoms caused by the diverticulum.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma with ESWR1 gene mutation. The technique shown in the image was performed to confirm the diagnosis. Identify the technique shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluorescent in situ hybridization

 

The technique shown in the image is FISH demonstrating a positive EWSR1 gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma.

 

The fused region denoted by Yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Karyotyping :

  • Karyotyping is a technique used to examine the number, size, and shape of chromosomes in a cell. While karyotyping can provide information about chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as specific as FISH in detecting the specific EWSR1 gene translocation associated with Ewing sarcoma.
  • Relevance: Karyotyping is a broader chromosome analysis technique and may not be the primary method for confirming Ewing sarcoma diagnosis.

 

Option C. Immunohistochemistry

  • Immunohistochemistry is a technique used to detect specific proteins in tissue samples. While it can be valuable in characterizing the tumor's protein expression, it may not directly confirm the presence of the EWSR1 gene mutation, which is a genetic abnormality.
  • Relevance: Immunohistochemistry can be used as a complementary technique to assess protein markers associated with Ewing sarcoma, but it may not be the primary method for confirming the genetic mutation.

 

Option D. Sanger's Technique

  •  Sanger sequencing is a method used for DNA sequencing. It is primarily used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA but may not be the technique of choice for confirming the specific EWSR1 gene mutation associated with Ewing sarcoma.
  • Relevance: Sanger sequencing is more focused on DNA sequence analysis rather than detecting gene translocations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situ hybridization is a modified version of DNA–DNA hybridization. If a metaphase spread chromosome preparation is probed with a gene, the location of the gene on a specific chromosome can be identified. The principle may be applied to histology slide also. In the tissue preparation, DNA is denatured, the specific probe tagged with fluorescent labels, incubated, washed and seen under a fluorescent (UV) microscope. The process is named as Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).

 

Applications of FISH are:

 

  1. Detects subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  2. Detects complex translocation
  3. Assessment of gene rearrangements in leukaemia
  4. Determination of amplification of HER2/neu in breast cancer
  5. Diagnosis of various types of lymphomas.

questions.text:
Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Spermatogonia

2. Primary spermatocyte

3. Spermatid

4. Spermatozoa

5. Myoepithelial cell
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5,1,2,3,4

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

 

In the seminiferous tubules, cells are organized in a specific sequence from the basal layer towards the lumen as part of the spermatogenesis process. The order reflects the developmental stages of sperm cells:

 

5. Myoepithelial cells: These cells, located at the basal layer, support the structure and function of the seminiferous tubules.

 

1. Spermatogonia: These are the stem cells located just above the basal membrane, which undergo mitotic divisions to produce more spermatogonia or differentiate into primary spermatocytes.

 

2. Primary spermatocytes:  Situated above the spermatogonia, these cells undergo meiosis I to form secondary spermatocytes.

 

3. Spermatid: Derived from the secondary spermatocytes after meiosis II, these cells are closer to the lumen and undergo spermiogenesis to become spermatozoa.

 

4. Spermatozoa: These are the final, mature male gametes that are nearest to the lumen of the tubule, ready to be released into the reproductive tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency room with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. After being administered an intravenous drug for treatment, he develops abnormal movements. Which of the following medications can be used to manage his abnormal movements? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzhexol

 

Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic agent often used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal involuntary movements. These symptoms can occur as a side effect of D2 blockers like antipsychotics and some antiemetics like metoclopramide that may have been used to treat the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: This is an antispasmodic and anticholinergic drug mainly used for motion sickness and gastrointestinal spasms. It is not specifically used for treating abnormal movements such as extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option B. Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine and anticholinergic medication used mainly for allergic reactions. It is not primarily indicated for the treatment of abnormal movements.

 

Option C. Levodopa: This medication is primarily used for treating Parkinson's disease and is not indicated for the treatment of drug-induced abnormal movements unless those symptoms are related to Parkinson’s disease.

 

Therefore, in this patient who developed abnormal movements possibly due to a drug side effect, Benzhexol would be the appropriate medication for managing his symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) is the drug of choice for managing extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal movements induced by medications such as D2 receptor blockers.

questions.text: Which fusion exocytosis complex is affected in tetanus?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synaptobrevin

 

Synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein), is one of the proteins involved in the SNARE complex, which plays a crucial role in mediating vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release at the synaptic cleft. In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin specifically targets and cleaves synaptobrevin, preventing the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA and glycine. This leads to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Snap 25: SNAP-25 (synaptosomal-associated protein 25) is another component of the SNARE complex involved in neurotransmitter release. It is not directly targeted by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option C. Syntaxin: Syntaxin is a third component of the SNARE complex, and like SNAP-25, it is not the primary target of the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option D. Synaptophysin: Synaptophysin is a synaptic vesicle membrane protein, but it is not directly involved in the SNARE complex or the process of exocytosis. It is not affected by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical students should understand that in tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin targets and affects synaptobrevin (VAMP), disrupting the SNARE complex and inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, leading to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis. This knowledge is important for understanding the pathophysiology of tetanus.

 

The light chain of tetanospasmin cleave the Gln76-Phe77 bond of synaptobrevin which is an integral V-SNARE necessary for vesicle fusion to membranes in CNS and thus by cleaving this SNARE, TeNT has the effect of interfering with exocytosis of neurotransmitters such as γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons causing violent spastic paralysis.

 

Ref- Ananthanarayan and Paniker 10th e/p 265

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with pain and swelling in the left side of his scrotum. The surgeon suspects testicular torsion based on the clinical presentation. Which is the most appropriate next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side

 

In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side.

 

  • This is the most appropriate next step in management for suspected testicular torsion. It involves immediate surgical exploration of both the symptomatic (painful) side and the asymptomatic (contralateral) side. Even if only one side appears to be affected, there is a risk of contralateral testicular torsion in future. This occurs as the same anatomical abnormality (high investment of tunica vaginalis/transverse testis are likely to be present on both sides.
  • The surgeon can detorse (untwist) the affected testicle and fixate it to prevent future torsion. Contralateral scrotum is explored and orchidopexy is done to prevent future risk of torsion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of testicular torsion: 

 

  • Timely diagnosis: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and requires prompt diagnosis and management to salvage the testis as the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.
  • Surgery: The definitive management of testicular torsion is surgical exploration with detorsion and fixation of the testis to prevent future torsion. The surgery should be performed within 6 hours of the onset of symptoms to maximize the chances of testicular salvage. At the time of surgical exploration contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed as the same anatomic defect can allow torsion on the contralateral side.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parainfluenza

 

Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

 

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

 

Management:

 

  • ﻿﻿Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.
  • Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • ﻿﻿Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>|V>|M). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • ﻿﻿Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (Sp02 <92 %)

 

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moraxella: More commonly associated with conditions like otitis media and sinusitis rather than croup.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Although capable of causing respiratory tract infections, it is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Known for more severe respiratory conditions like bacterial tracheitis, which is distinct from viral croup and presents with more severe symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza is a common cause of croup. The 'Steeple sign' on X-ray supports this diagnosis, emphasizing the need for prompt and effective treatment to ensure rapid recovery and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to sudden onset of noisy breathing and difficulty inhaling. The parents report that the child has had a fever, runny nose, and sore throat for the past two days, but the breathing problem began abruptly this morning. On examination, the child is in moderate respiratory distress with inspiratory stridor, worsened by crying or agitation. There is no drooling or muffling of the voice, and his oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Based on the clinical presentation, inspiratory stridor is most commonly associated with lesions in which part of the airway?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Supraglottic region


Inspiratory stridor is a hallmark of obstruction in the supraglottic region, which includes the pharynx, epiglottis, and structures above the vocal cords. This type of stridor occurs during inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure, which exacerbates the collapse or narrowing of the supraglottic structures. Conditions like laryngomalacia, epiglottitis, or foreign body aspiration in the supraglottic region are typical causes, and recognizing the inspiratory nature of the stridor helps localize the site of the obstruction.

 

 

Other Options:


Option B. Subglottic region: The subglottic area below the vocal cords usually produces biphasic stridor (both inspiratory and expiratory) due to its involvement in both phases of breathing.

 

Option C. Thoracic trachea: Lesions in the thoracic trachea commonly cause expiratory stridor because the obstruction impacts airflow during exhalation rather than inhalation.

 

Option D. Mainstem bronchi: Obstructions in the mainstem bronchi typically present with wheezing or diminished breath sounds rather than stridor, as these regions are deeper within the lower airway.

 

Educational Objective:


Inspiratory stridor is most commonly associated with obstructions in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing the specific type of stridor aids in diagnosing the anatomical location of the obstruction and guides appropriate management.

choices.text: Inherited defect in PIG-A
Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

questions.text: Which of the following is true about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is characterized by a deficiency in the proteins CD55 and CD59, which normally protect red blood cells from immune attack. This deficiency is caused by a mutation in the PIG-A gene on the X chromosome, which is acquired (not inherited) and results in the failure to attach these protective proteins to the cell membrane. Without these proteins, red blood cells become susceptible to destruction by the complement system, a part of the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inherited defect in PIG-A: This statement is incorrect. The defect in the PIG-A gene associated with PNH is acquired, not inherited.

 

Option B. Extravascular hemolysis: PNH primarily causes intravascular hemolysis, not extravascular. This is because the unregulated activation of the complement system leads to the lysis of red blood cells within the circulatory system.

 

Option D. Microcytic anemia: PNH typically results in normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. The anemia in PNH is due to the destruction of red blood cells by the complement system, which affects cells of normal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The true hallmark of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is the deficiency of CD55 and CD59 on the surface of blood cells, leading to increased vulnerability to lysis by the complement system and resulting in intravascular hemolysis. This understanding is critical for the correct diagnosis and management of PNH.

 

Reference - Harrison/PNH/Chapter 100

choices.text: Epithelial cells covered by bacteria
Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods
Doderlein bacili in the macrophage

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes in with a grayish-white vaginal discharge. Upon conducting a gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are observed. What are clue cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epithelial cells covered by bacteria

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells that are covered by bacteria, which gives them a distinctive appearance. In the context of bacterial vaginosis, these cells appear with a fuzzy or irregular border due to the presence of small gram-negative bacilli adhering to their surface. The presence of clue cells is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis, a condition caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Degranulated neutrophils: Degranulated neutrophils are not clue cells. Neutrophils are involved in the immune response, and their degranulation refers to the release of granules that contain enzymes and other substances. They do not have the fuzzy appearance characteristic of clue cells.

 

Option C. Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods: Gardenella vaginalis is a bacterium associated with bacterial vaginosis, but clue cells are not specifically Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods. Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by various types of bacteria, not a specific bacterium or rod-shaped bacteria.

 

Option D. Doderlein bacilli in the macrophage: Doderlein bacilli (lactobacilli) are normally present in the vagina and help maintain a healthy environment. They are not found within macrophages, nor are they related to the appearance of clue cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by bacteria, and their presence is indicative of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

 

KAWASAKI DISEASE MNEMONIC

 

CRASH & Burn

 

  • Conjunctivitis (non-purulent)
  • Rash
  • Adenopathy (cervical and commonly unilateral)
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Hands (palmar erythema/ swelling)
  • Burn (fever lasting at least 5 days or more)

 

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction.

 

Rx: Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Option D. Henoch-Schönlein purpura is an acute, systemic, immune complex-mediated, leukocytoclastic vasculitis. It is characterized by a clinical triad of palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), abdominal pain, and arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is characterized by a persistent fever, erythematous and polymorphous rash, edema of hands and feet, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It primarily affects children under 4 years old and can lead to serious coronary artery complications if not treated appropriately.
